----- Original Message -----
From: "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>


>
> If the interface isn't allowed to change, then we have a real problem.
> Software changes. Any time change is painful, change is discouraged.
> When change is discouraged, we reduce the likelihood of delivering the
> right software. My mission is to deliver the right software, so when
> the interface isn't allowed to change, I can't do my job.
>

Well of course, all things need to change from time to time, and should be
allowed to do so - but constantly changing interfaces, or interfaces that
change drastically, are an indication that there is something wrong - either
in the process or in the code. I am not saying that interfaces shouldn't be
allowed to change, but at some point they should become stable - and that
point is usually reached long before an independent unit tester get's their
hands on the unit.

> So explain to me the difference between what you describe and Pair
> Programming combined with TDD. Is it just that other programmers are,
> on their own, writing tests for my stuff after I've written it?

There can be. As with all things, team structure, process and methodology
can be tweaked to suit the team and the project. As you stated, TDD is not
primarily meant to find bugs, whereas independent unit testing is very good
at that, and generally that is its primary purpose; early testing. If you
have an XP team that is so good that they write perfect code, and a *good*
independent unit tester can't find any bugs in the code, then don't use
independent unit testers and more power to you. But I have yet to see such a
team or such developers - and I feel fairly confident that I could write
unit tests that would find significant bugs in just about any new codebase
under development - including a codebase developed using TDD.

FWIW,
Lauren
